Description: Body sherd of Silhouette Style Corinthian pottery plate; interior, from centre: part of grazing goat to left (head, beard, forelegs, underbelly, part of one hind leg); hailstorm as filling ornament; black band and added red band; frieze with traces of animals (perhaps top of panther's head to right and horns and top of back of grazing goat to left) with hailstorm as filling ornament; exterior: reserved with black band near centre, red band further out.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
For a parallel, see Boardman, 'Early Greek Vase Painting', Thames and Hudson, London (1998), p. 193, fig. 383 (from Tocra). The sherd possibly belongs to the same vase as Louvre AM1362 (16).
Bibliographic references: Payne 1931 / Necrocorinthia. A study of corinthian art in the archaic period (Catalogue, no. 1037)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 93, no. A124)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 219, no. 37)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 72, pl. 6, no. 16.)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.264)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
